qas.question: What do most Western languages use in their written form to add clarity?
What are writing systems which make no distinction between majuscales and minuscules often referred to as?
Which alphabet is a special case because it transitioned from bicameral to unicameral?
What are scripts that utilized two seperate cases called?

context: Most Western languages (particularly those with writing systems based on the Latin, Cyrillic, Greek, Coptic, and Armenian alphabets) use <a0_0>letter cases<a0_0/> in their written form as an aid to clarity. Scripts using two separate cases are also called <a3_0>bicameral<a3_0/> scripts. Many other writing systems make no distinction between majuscules and minuscules – a system called <a1_0>unicameral script<a1_0/> or unicase. This includes most syllabic and other non-alphabetic scripts. The <a2_0>Georgian<a2_0/> alphabet is special since it used to be bicameral, but today is mostly used in a unicameral way.
